intro: Acacia viscifolia, commonly known as the sticky acacia, is a shrub native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its slender, often twisted branches and small, yellowish-green flowers that appear in compact clusters. The plant produces pod-like fruits that contain several seeds, and its leaves are bipinnate, meaning they are divided into small, feather-like segments. Acacia viscifolia is adapted to arid environments and has a symbiotic relationship with nitrogen-fixing bacteria. It is often used in traditional medicine and as a source of gum arabic.

Its genus is Acacia, a group of shrubs and trees known for their distinctive phyllodes and ability to thrive in arid environments. Its species is Acacia viscifolia, a specific type of acacia known for its sticky leaves and preference for coastal and sandy habitats.

This plant thrives in dry, sandy soils and is often seen in open woodlands and heathlands. It is well adapted to the arid and semi-arid climates of its native habitat. Acacia viscifolia plays an important ecological role in supporting local wildlife and maintaining soil stability.
